It is the [seventh-largest country by area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area "List of countries and dependencies by area"); the [most populous country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population_(United_Nations) "List of countries by population (United Nations)") since 2023;[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-31) and, since its independence in 1947, the world's most populous democracy.[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2012327%22Even_though_much_remains_to_be_done,_especially_in_regard_to_eradicating_poverty_and_securing_effective_structures_of_governance,_India's_achievements_since_independence_in_sustaining_freedom_and_democracy_have_been_singular_among_the_world's_new_nations.%22-32)[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-stein-arnold-33)[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFisher2018184%E2%80%93185-34) Bounded by the [Indian Ocean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian Ocean") on the south, the [Arabian Sea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabian_Sea "Arabian Sea") on the southwest, and the [Bay of Bengal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal "Bay of Bengal") on the southeast, it shares land borders with [Pakistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan") to the west;[\[k\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-36) [China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China "China"), [Nepal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nepal "Nepal"), and [Bhutan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhutan "Bhutan") to the north; and [Bangladesh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh") and [Myanmar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myanmar "Myanmar") to the east. In the [Indian Ocean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Ocean "Indian Ocean"), India is near [Sri Lanka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri Lanka") and the [Maldives](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maldives "Maldives"); its [Andaman and Nicobar Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andaman_and_Nicobar_Islands "Andaman and Nicobar Islands") share a [maritime border](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maritime_boundary "Maritime boundary") with [Thailand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thailand "Thailand"), [Myanmar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myanmar "Myanmar"), and [Indonesia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indonesia "Indonesia"). [Modern humans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_humans "Modern humans") arrived on the [Indian subcontinent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_subcontinent "Indian subcontinent") from [Africa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Africa "Africa") no later than 55,000 years ago.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-PetragliaAllchin-37)[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Dyson2018p1-38)[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Fisher2018p23-39) Their long occupation, predominantly in isolation as hunter-gatherers, has made the region highly diverse.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Dyson2018-28a-40) [Settled life](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neolithic "Neolithic") emerged on the subcontinent in the western margins of the [Indus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indus_River "Indus River") [river basin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/River_basin "River basin") 9,000 years ago, evolving gradually into the [Indus Valley Civilisation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation "Indus Valley Civilisation") of the third millennium BCE.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Combined-2-41) By 1200 BCE, an [archaic form](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proto-language "Proto-language") of [Sanskrit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanskrit "Sanskrit"), an [Indo-European language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-European_language "Indo-European language"), had [diffused](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trans-cultural_diffusion "Trans-cultural diffusion") into India from the northwest.[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-42)[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Combined-4-Rigveda-43) [Its hymns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rig_Veda "Rig Veda") recorded the [early dawnings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion "Historical Vedic religion") of [Hinduism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hinduism "Hinduism") in India.[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Combined-3-44) India's pre-existing [Dravidian languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dravidian_languages "Dravidian languages") were supplanted in the northern regions.[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Combined-4-45) By 400 BCE, [caste](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caste "Caste") had emerged within Hinduism,[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Dyson2018-16a-46) and [Buddhism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Buddhism_in_India "History of Buddhism in India") and [Jainism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Jainism "History of Jainism") had arisen, proclaiming [social orders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_order "Social order") unlinked to heredity.[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Fisher2018-59-47) Early political consolidations gave rise to the loose-knit [Maurya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurya_Empire "Maurya Empire") and [Gupta Empires](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gupta_Empire "Gupta Empire").[\[37\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Combined-5-48) Widespread creativity suffused this era,[\[38\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Combined-6-49) but the status of women declined,[\[39\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Combined-7-50) and [untouchability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Untouchability "Untouchability") became an organized belief.[\[l\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-52)[\[40\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200493-51) In [South India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_India "South India"), the [Middle kingdoms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_kingdoms_of_India#The_Deccan_plateau_and_South "Middle kingdoms of India") exported Dravidian language scripts and religious cultures to the kingdoms of [Southeast Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southeast_Asia "Southeast Asia").[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-AsherAsher2006-17-53) In the early medieval era, [Christianity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christianity "Christianity"), [Islam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islam "Islam"), [Judaism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judaism "Judaism"), and [Zoroastrianism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zoroastrianism "Zoroastrianism") became established on India's southern and western coasts.[\[42\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Combined-8-54) Muslim armies from [Central Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Asia "Central Asia") intermittently overran India's northern plains in the second millennium.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Combined-13-55) The resulting [Delhi Sultanate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate "Delhi Sultanate") drew northern India into the cosmopolitan [networks of medieval Islam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_Golden_Age "Islamic Golden Age").[\[44\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Combined-10-56) In south India, the [Vijayanagara Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire "Vijayanagara Empire") created a long-lasting composite Hindu culture.[\[45\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-AsherAsher2006-74-57) In the [Punjab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjab "Punjab"), [Sikhism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sikhism "Sikhism") emerged, rejecting institutionalised religion.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-AsherAsher2006-267-58) The [Mughal Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mughal_Empire "Mughal Empire") ushered in two centuries of economic expansion and relative peace,[\[47\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-AsherAsher2006-152-59) leaving a rich [architectural legacy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mughal_architecture "Mughal architecture").[\[48\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Fisher2018-106-60)[\[49\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-asher-mughal-architecture-61) Gradually expanding [rule of the British East India Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Company_rule_in_India "Company rule in India") turned India into a colonial economy but consolidated its [sovereignty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sovereignty "Sovereignty").[\[50\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Combined-11-62) [British Crown rule](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj") began in 1858. The rights promised to Indians were granted slowly,[\[51\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Combined-12-63)[\[52\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPeers2013[httpsbooksgooglecombooksiddyQuAgAAQBAJpgPA76_76]-64) but [technological changes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_Revolution "Industrial Revolution") were introduced, and modern ideas of education and the public life took root.[\[53\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-EmbreeHay1988-65) A [nationalist movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_independence_movement "Indian independence movement") emerged in India, the first in the non-European [British empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_empire "British empire") and an influence on other nationalist movements.[\[54\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Marshall2001-66)[\[55\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Chiriyankandath2016-67) Noted for nonviolent resistance after 1920,[\[56\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-metcalf-metcalf-gandhi-1920-68) it became the primary factor in ending British rule.[\[57\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-stein-arnold-successful-nationalism-69) In 1947, the British Indian Empire was [partitioned](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partition_of_India "Partition of India") into two independent [dominions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominion#India_and_Pakistan "Dominion"),[\[58\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-fisher-partition-70)[\[59\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-chatterji-partition-71)[\[60\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-talbot-sing-72)[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-khan-great-partition-73) a Hindu-majority [dominion of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominion_of_India "Dominion of India") and a Muslim-majority [dominion of Pakistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominion_of_Pakistan "Dominion of Pakistan"). A large-scale loss of life and an unprecedented migration accompanied the partition.[\[62\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-74) India has been a [federal republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_republic "Federal republic") since 1950, governed through a democratic [parliamentary system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliamentary_system "Parliamentary system"). It is a [pluralistic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pluralism_(political_philosophy) "Pluralism (political philosophy)"), [multilingual](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multilingualism "Multilingualism") and [multi-ethnic society](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiculturalism "Multiculturalism"). India's population grew from 361 million in 1951 to over 1.4 billion in 2023.[\[63\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Dyson2018-219-75) During this time, its nominal [per capita income](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Per_capita_income "Per capita income") increased from US$64 annually to US$2,601, and its literacy rate from 16.6% to 74%. A comparatively destitute country in 1951,[\[64\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Fisher2018-8-76) India has become a [fast-growing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate "List of countries by real GDP growth rate") major economy and [hub for information technology services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_technology_in_India "Information technology in India"); it has an expanding middle class.[\[65\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-MetcalfMetcalf2012-265-77) [Indian movies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cinema_of_India "Cinema of India") and [music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_of_India "Music of India") increasingly influence global culture.[\[66\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-MetcalfMetcalf2012-266-78) India has reduced [its poverty rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poverty_in_India "Poverty in India"), though at the cost of increasing economic inequality.[\[67\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Dyson2018-216-a-79) It is a [nuclear-weapon state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons "List of states with nuclear weapons") that [ranks high in military expenditure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures "List of countries by military expenditures"). It has disputes over [Kashmir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kashmir "Kashmir") with its neighbours, Pakistan and China, unresolved since the mid-20th century.[\[68\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-kashmir-disputes-80) Among the socio-economic challenges India faces are [gender inequality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gender_inequality_in_India "Gender inequality in India"), [child malnutrition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malnutrition_in_India "Malnutrition in India"),[\[69\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-NarayanJohn2018-lead-81) and rising levels of [air pollution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_pollution_in_India "Air pollution in India").[\[70\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-BalakrishnanDey2019-lead-82) India's land is [megadiverse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megadiverse_country "Megadiverse country") with four [biodiversity hotspots](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_hotspots "Biodiversity hotspots").[\[71\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-IUCN-India-83) [India's wildlife](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildlife_of_India "Wildlife of India"), which has traditionally been viewed with tolerance in [its culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Culture_of_India "Culture of India"),[\[72\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKaranthGopal2005374-84) is supported in [protected habitats](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protected_areas_of_India "Protected areas of India"). ## Etymology Main article: [Names for India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Names_for_India "Names for India") According to the _[Oxford English Dictionary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary "Oxford English Dictionary")_ (2009), the name "India" is derived from the [Classical Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_Latin "Classical Latin") _India_, a reference to [South Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Asia "South Asia") and an uncertain region to its east. In turn "India" derived successively from [Hellenistic Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hellenistic_Greek "Hellenistic Greek") _India_ (Ἰνδία), [Ancient Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek "Ancient Greek") _Indos_ (Ἰνδός), [Old Persian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Persian "Old Persian") _[Hindush](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindush "Hindush")_ (an eastern province of the [Achaemenid Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire "Achaemenid Empire")), and ultimately its [cognate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognate "Cognate"), the [Sanskrit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanskrit "Sanskrit") _Sindhu_, or 'river'—specifically the [Indus River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indus_River "Indus River"), and by extension its well-settled southern basin.[\[73\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-85)[\[74\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThieme1970447%E2%80%93450-86) The [Ancient Greeks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greeks "Ancient Greeks") referred to the Indians as _Indoi_, 'the people of the Indus'.[\[75\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKuiper201086-87) The term _[Bharat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Names_for_India#Bharat "Names for India")_ (_Bhārat_; pronounced[\[ˈbʱaːɾət\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/Hindi_and_Urdu "Help:IPA/Hindi and Urdu")[Play audio](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/79/Hi-Bharat.ogg/Hi-Bharat.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")[ⓘ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Hi-Bharat.ogg "File:Hi-Bharat.ogg")), mentioned in both [Indian epic poetry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_epic_poetry "Indian epic poetry") and the [Constitution of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_India "Constitution of India"),[\[76\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECl%C3%A9mentin-Ojha2014-88)[\[77\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-89) is used in its variations by [many Indian languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Names_for_India "Names for India"). A modern rendering of the historical name _Bharatavarsha_, which applied originally to [North India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_India "North India"),[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Jha2014-90)[\[79\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2017[httpsbooksgooglecombooksiddYM4DwAAQBAJpgPA253_253]-91) _Bharat_ gained increased currency from the mid-19th century as a native name for India.[\[76\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECl%C3%A9mentin-Ojha2014-88)[\[80\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarrow2003-92) _[Hindustan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindustan "Hindustan")_ ([\[ɦɪndʊˈstaːn\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/Hindi_and_Urdu "Help:IPA/Hindi and Urdu")[Play audio](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/4/46/Hindustan.ogg/Hindustan.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")[ⓘ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Hindustan.ogg "File:Hindustan.ogg")) is a [Middle Persian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_Persian "Middle Persian") name for India that became popular by the 13th century,[\[81\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-93) and was used widely since the era of the [Mughal Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mughal_Empire "Mughal Empire"). The meaning of _Hindustan_ has varied, referring to a region encompassing the northern [Indian subcontinent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_subcontinent "Indian subcontinent") (present-day northern India and [Pakistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan")) or to India in its near entirety.[\[76\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECl%C3%A9mentin-Ojha2014-88)[\[80\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarrow2003-92)[\[82\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-94) ## History Main articles: [History of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_India "History of India") and [History of the Republic of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_Republic_of_India "History of the Republic of India") ### Ancient India [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Battle_at_Lanka%2C_Ramayana%2C_Udaipur%2C_1649-53.jpg/500px-Battle_at_Lanka%2C_Ramayana%2C_Udaipur%2C_1649-53.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Battle_at_Lanka,_Ramayana,_Udaipur,_1649-53.jpg) Manuscript illustration, c. 1650, of the Sanskrit epic [Ramayana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramayana "Ramayana"), composed in story-telling fashion c. 400 BCE – c. 300 CE[\[83\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Lowe2017-epic-95) By 55,000 years ago, the first modern humans, or _[Homo sapiens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homo_sapiens "Homo sapiens")_, had arrived on the Indian subcontinent from Africa.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-PetragliaAllchin-37)[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Dyson2018p1-38)[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Fisher2018p23-39) The earliest known modern human remains in South Asia date to about 30,000 years ago.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-PetragliaAllchin-37) After 6500 BCE, evidence for domestication of food crops and animals, construction of permanent structures, and storage of agricultural surplus appeared in [Mehrgarh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mehrgarh "Mehrgarh") and other sites in [Balochistan, Pakistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Balochistan,_Pakistan "Balochistan, Pakistan").[\[84\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConinghamYoung2015104%E2%80%93105-96) These gradually developed into the [Indus Valley Civilisation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indus_Valley_Civilisation "Indus Valley Civilisation"),[\[85\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200421%E2%80%9323-97)[\[84\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConinghamYoung2015104%E2%80%93105-96) the first urban culture in South Asia,[\[86\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009181-98) which flourished during 2500–1900 BCE in Pakistan and western India.[\[87\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPossehl20032-99) Centred around cities such as [Mohenjo-daro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohenjo-daro "Mohenjo-daro"), [Harappa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harappa "Harappa"), [Dholavira](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dholavira "Dholavira"), and [Kalibangan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalibangan "Kalibangan"), and relying on varied forms of subsistence, the civilisation engaged robustly in crafts production and wide-ranging trade.[\[86\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009181-98) During the period 2000–500 BCE, many regions of the subcontinent transitioned from the [Chalcolithic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chalcolithic "Chalcolithic") cultures to the [Iron Age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iron_Age "Iron Age") ones.[\[88\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009255-100) The [Vedas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vedas "Vedas"), the oldest scriptures associated with [Hinduism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hinduism "Hinduism"),[\[89\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009186%E2%80%93187-101) were composed during this period,[\[90\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWitzel200368%E2%80%9369-102) and historians have analysed these to posit a [Vedic culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vedic_period "Vedic period") in the [Punjab region](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Punjab_region "Punjab region") and the upper [Gangetic Plain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain "Indo-Gangetic Plain").[\[88\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009255-100) Most historians also consider this period to have encompassed several waves of [Indo-Aryan migration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Aryan_migration "Indo-Aryan migration") into the subcontinent from the north-west.[\[89\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009186%E2%80%93187-101) The [caste system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caste_system "Caste system"), which created a hierarchy of priests, warriors, and free peasants, but which excluded indigenous peoples by labelling their occupations impure, arose during this period.[\[91\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200441%E2%80%9343-103) On the [Deccan Plateau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deccan_Plateau "Deccan Plateau"), archaeological evidence from this period suggests the existence of a chiefdom stage of political organisation.[\[88\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009255-100) In [South India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_India "South India"), a progression to sedentary life is indicated by the large number of [megalithic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megalith "Megalith") monuments dating from this period,[\[92\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009250%E2%80%93251-104) as well as by nearby traces of [agriculture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agriculture "Agriculture"), [irrigation tanks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irrigation_tanks "Irrigation tanks"), and craft traditions.[\[92\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009250%E2%80%93251-104) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Cave_26%2C_Ajanta.jpg/500px-Cave_26%2C_Ajanta.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Cave_26,_Ajanta.jpg) Cave 26 of the rock-cut [Ajanta Caves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajanta_Caves "Ajanta Caves") In the late Vedic period, around the 6th century BCE, the small states and chiefdoms of the Ganges Plain and the north-western regions had consolidated into 16 major oligarchies and monarchies that were known as the _[mahajanapadas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahajanapadas "Mahajanapadas")_.[\[93\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009260%E2%80%93265-105)[\[94\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200453%E2%80%9354-106) The emerging urbanisation gave rise to non-Vedic religious movements, two of which became independent religions. [Jainism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jainism "Jainism") came into prominence during the life of its exemplar, [Mahavira](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahavira "Mahavira").[\[95\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009312%E2%80%93313-107) [Buddhism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism"), based on the teachings of [Gautama Buddha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gautama_Buddha "Gautama Buddha"), attracted followers from all social classes excepting the middle class; chronicling the life of the Buddha was central to the beginnings of recorded history in India.[\[96\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200454%E2%80%9356-108)[\[97\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein199821-109)[\[98\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein199867%E2%80%9368-110) In an age of increasing urban wealth, both religions held up [renunciation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nekkhamma "Nekkhamma") as an ideal,[\[99\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009300-111) and both established long-lasting monastic traditions. Politically, by the 3rd century BCE, the kingdom of [Magadha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magadha_(Mahajanapada) "Magadha (Mahajanapada)") had annexed or reduced other states to emerge as the [Maurya Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurya_Empire "Maurya Empire").[\[100\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009319-112) The empire was once thought to have controlled most of the subcontinent except the far south, but its core regions are now thought to have been separated by large autonomous areas.[\[101\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein199878%E2%80%9379-113)[\[102\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200470-114) The Mauryan kings are known as much for their empire-building and determined management of public life as for [Ashoka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashoka "Ashoka")'s renunciation of militarism and far-flung advocacy of the Buddhist _[dhamma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dharma_(Buddhism) "Dharma (Buddhism)")_.[\[103\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009367-115)[\[104\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200463-116) The [Sangam literature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sangam_literature "Sangam literature") of the [Tamil language](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamil_language "Tamil language") reveals that, between 200 BCE and 200 CE, the southern peninsula was ruled by the [Cheras](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chera_dynasty "Chera dynasty"), the [Cholas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chola_dynasty "Chola dynasty"), and the [Pandyas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pandya_dynasty "Pandya dynasty"), dynasties that [traded extensively with the Roman Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Roman_trade_relations "Indo-Roman trade relations") and with [West](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Asia "Western Asia") and [Southeast Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southeast_Asia "Southeast Asia").[\[105\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein199889%E2%80%9390-117)[\[106\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009408%E2%80%93415-118) In North India, Hinduism asserted patriarchal control within the family, leading to increased subordination of women.[\[107\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein199892%E2%80%9395-119)[\[100\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009319-112) By the 4th and 5th centuries, the [Gupta Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gupta_Empire "Gupta Empire") had created a complex system of administration and taxation in the greater Ganges Plain; this system became a model for later Indian kingdoms.[\[108\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund200489%E2%80%9391-120)[\[109\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009545-121) Under the Guptas, a renewed Hinduism based on devotion, rather than the management of ritual, began to assert itself.[\[110\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein199898%E2%80%9399-122) This renewal was reflected in a flowering of [sculpture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sculpture_in_the_Indian_subcontinent "Sculpture in the Indian subcontinent") and [architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Architecture_of_India "Architecture of India"), which found patrons among an urban elite.[\[109\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009545-121) [Classical Sanskrit literature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanskrit_literature#Classical_Sanskrit_literature "Sanskrit literature") flowered as well, and [Indian science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_the_Indian_subcontinent "History of science and technology in the Indian subcontinent"), [astronomy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_astronomy "Indian astronomy"), [medicine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ayurveda "Ayurveda"), and [mathematics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_mathematics "Indian mathematics") made significant advances.[\[109\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2009545-121) ### Medieval India Main article: [Medieval India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medieval_India "Medieval India") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Gopuram_Corner_View_of_Thanjavur_Brihadeeswara_Temple..JPG/500px-Gopuram_Corner_View_of_Thanjavur_Brihadeeswara_Temple..JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Gopuram_Corner_View_of_Thanjavur_Brihadeeswara_Temple..JPG) [Brihadeshwara temple](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brihadeshwara_temple "Brihadeshwara temple"), [Thanjavur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thanjavur "Thanjavur"), completed in 1010 CE[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg/500px-Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Qutb_minar_ruins.jpg) The [Qutub Minar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qutub_Minar "Qutub Minar"), 73 m (240 ft) tall, completed by the [Sultan of Delhi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sultan_of_Delhi "Sultan of Delhi"), [Iltutmish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iltutmish "Iltutmish") The Indian early medieval age, from 600 to 1200 CE, is defined by regional kingdoms and cultural diversity.[\[111\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998132-123) When [Harsha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harsha "Harsha") of [Kannauj](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kannauj "Kannauj"), who ruled much of the Indo-Gangetic Plain from 606 to 647 CE, attempted to expand southwards, he was defeated by the [Chalukya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chalukya_dynasty "Chalukya dynasty") ruler of the Deccan.[\[112\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998119%E2%80%93120-124) When his successor attempted to expand eastwards, he was defeated by the [Pala](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pala_Empire "Pala Empire") king of [Bengal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bengal "Bengal").[\[112\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998119%E2%80%93120-124) When the Chalukyas attempted to expand southwards, they were defeated by the [Pallavas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pallava_dynasty "Pallava dynasty") from farther south, who in turn were opposed by the [Pandyas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pandya_dynasty "Pandya dynasty") and the [Cholas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chola_dynasty "Chola dynasty") from still farther south.[\[112\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998119%E2%80%93120-124) No ruler of this period was able to create an empire and consistently control lands much beyond their core region.[\[111\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998132-123) During this time, pastoral peoples, whose land had been cleared to make way for the growing agricultural economy, were accommodated within caste society, as were new non-traditional ruling classes.[\[113\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998121%E2%80%93122-125) The caste system consequently began to show regional differences.[\[113\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998121%E2%80%93122-125) In the 6th and 7th centuries, the first [devotional hymns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhakti "Bhakti") were created in the Tamil language.[\[114\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998123-126) They were imitated all over India and led to both the resurgence of Hinduism and the development of all [modern languages of the subcontinent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Languages_of_India "Languages of India").[\[114\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998123-126) Indian royalty, big and small, and the temples they patronised drew citizens in great numbers to the capital cities, which became economic hubs as well.[\[115\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998124-127) Temple towns of various sizes began to appear everywhere as India underwent another urbanisation.[\[115\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998124-127) By the 8th and 9th centuries, the effects were felt in Southeast Asia, as South Indian culture and political systems were exported to lands that became part of modern-day [Myanmar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Myanmar "Myanmar"), [Thailand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thailand "Thailand"), [Laos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laos "Laos"), [Brunei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brunei "Brunei"), [Cambodia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cambodia "Cambodia"), [Vietnam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnam "Vietnam"), [Philippines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philippines "Philippines"), [Malaysia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malaysia "Malaysia"), and [Indonesia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indonesia "Indonesia").[\[116\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998127%E2%80%93128-128) Indian merchants, scholars, and sometimes armies were involved in this transmission; Southeast Asians took the initiative as well, with many sojourning in Indian seminaries and translating Buddhist and Hindu texts into their languages.[\[116\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998127%E2%80%93128-128) After the 10th century, Muslim Central Asian nomadic clans, using [swift-horse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Courser_(horse) "Courser (horse)") cavalry and raising vast armies united by ethnicity and religion, repeatedly overran South Asia's north-western plains, leading eventually to the establishment of the Islamic [Delhi Sultanate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Sultanate "Delhi Sultanate") in 1206.[\[117\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTELudden200268-129) The sultanate was to control much of North India and to make many forays into South India. Although at first disruptive for the Indian elites, the sultanate largely left its vast non-Muslim subject population to its own laws and customs.[\[118\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200847-130)[\[119\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf20066-131) By repeatedly repulsing [Mongol raiders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mongol_Empire "Mongol Empire") in the 13th century, the sultanate saved India from the devastation visited on West and Central Asia, setting the scene for centuries of [migration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_migration "Human migration") of fleeing soldiers, learned men, mystics, traders, artists, and artisans from that region into the subcontinent, thereby creating a syncretic Indo-Islamic culture in the north.[\[120\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTELudden200267-132)[\[121\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200850%E2%80%9351-133) The sultanate's raiding and weakening of the regional kingdoms of South India paved the way for the indigenous [Vijayanagara Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vijayanagara_Empire "Vijayanagara Empire").[\[122\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200853-134) Embracing a strong [Shaivite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shaivism "Shaivism") tradition and building upon the military technology of the sultanate, the empire came to control much of peninsular India,[\[123\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200612-135) and was to influence South Indian society for long afterwards.[\[122\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot200853-134) ### Early modern India [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Agra_Fort_DistantTaj.JPG/500px-Agra_Fort_DistantTaj.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Agra_Fort_DistantTaj.JPG) A distant view of the [Taj Mahal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taj_Mahal "Taj Mahal") from the [Agra Fort](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agra_Fort "Agra Fort")[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg/500px-India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:India_1835_2_Mohurs.jpg) A two [mohur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohur "Mohur") Company gold coin, issued in 1835, the [obverse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obverse_and_reverse "Obverse and reverse") inscribed " [William IIII](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_IV "William IV"), King" In the early 16th century, northern India, then under mainly Muslim rulers,[\[124\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobb200180-136) fell again to the superior mobility and firepower of a new generation of Central Asian warriors.[\[125\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998164-137) The resulting [Mughal Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mughal_Empire "Mughal Empire") did not stamp out the local societies it came to rule. Instead, it balanced and pacified them through new administrative practices[\[126\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008115-138)[\[127\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobb200190%E2%80%9391-139) and diverse and inclusive ruling elites,[\[128\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200617-140) leading to more systematic, centralised, and uniform rule.[\[129\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008152-141) Eschewing tribal bonds and Islamic identity, especially under [Akbar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akbar "Akbar"), the Mughals united their far-flung realms through loyalty, expressed through a Persianised culture, to an emperor who had near-divine status.[\[128\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200617-140) The Mughal state's economic policies, deriving most revenues from agriculture[\[130\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008158-142) and mandating that taxes be paid in the well-regulated silver currency,[\[131\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998169-143) caused peasants and artisans to enter larger markets.[\[129\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008152-141) The relative peace maintained by the empire during much of the 17th century was a factor in India's economic expansion,[\[129\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008152-141) resulting in greater patronage of [painting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mughal_painting "Mughal painting"), literary forms, textiles, and [architecture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mughal_architecture "Mughal architecture").[\[132\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008186-144) Newly coherent social groups in northern and western India, such as the [Marathas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maratha_Empire "Maratha Empire"), the [Rajputs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajput "Rajput"), and the [Sikhs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sikh_Empire "Sikh Empire"), gained military and governing ambitions during Mughal rule, which, through collaboration or adversity, gave them both recognition and military experience.[\[133\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200623%E2%80%9324-145) Expanding commerce during Mughal rule gave rise to new Indian commercial and political elites along the coasts of southern and eastern India.[\[133\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200623%E2%80%9324-145) As the empire disintegrated, many among these elites were able to seek and control their own affairs.[\[134\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008256-146) By the early 18th century, with the lines between commercial and political dominance being increasingly blurred, a number of European trading companies, including the [English East India Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_India_Company "East India Company"), had established coastal outposts.[\[135\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008286-147)[\[136\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200644%E2%80%9349-148) The East India Company's control of the seas, greater resources, and more advanced military training and technology led it to increasingly assert its military strength and caused it to become attractive to a portion of the Indian elite; these factors were crucial in allowing the company to gain control over the [Bengal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bengal "Bengal") region by 1765 and sideline the other European companies.[\[137\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobb200198%E2%80%93100-149)[\[135\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008286-147)[\[138\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTELudden2002128%E2%80%93132-150)[\[139\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200651%E2%80%9355-151) Its further access to the riches of Bengal and the subsequent increased strength and size of its army enabled it to annex or subdue most of India by the 1820s.[\[140\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200668%E2%80%9371-152) India was then no longer exporting manufactured goods as it long had, but was instead supplying the [British Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") with raw materials. Many historians consider this to be the onset of India's colonial period.[\[135\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008286-147) By this time, with its economic power severely curtailed by the British parliament and having effectively been made an arm of British administration, the East India Company began more consciously to enter non-economic arenas, including education, social reform, and culture.[\[141\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAsherTalbot2008289-153) ### Modern India Main article: [History of India (1947–present)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_India_(1947%E2%80%93present) "History of India (1947–present)") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg/500px-British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:British_Indian_Empire_1909_Imperial_Gazetteer_of_India.jpg) 1909 map of the British Indian Empire[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Nehru_Ghandi_AP_18050506381948_%28cropped%29.jpg/500px-Nehru_Ghandi_AP_18050506381948_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Nehru_Ghandi_AP_18050506381948_(cropped).jpg) [Jawaharlal Nehru](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru "Jawaharlal Nehru") sharing a light moment with [Mahatma Gandhi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi "Mahatma Gandhi"), Mumbai, 6 July 1946 Historians consider India's modern age to have begun sometime between 1848 and 1885. The appointment in 1848 of [Lord Dalhousie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Broun-Ramsay,_1st_Marquess_of_Dalhousie "James Broun-Ramsay, 1st Marquess of Dalhousie") as Governor General of the East India Company set the stage for changes essential to a modern state. These included the consolidation and demarcation of sovereignty, the surveillance of the population, and the education of citizens. Technological changes—among them, railways, canals, and the telegraph—were introduced not long after their introduction in [Europe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Europe "Europe").[\[142\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobb2001151%E2%80%93152-154)[\[143\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200694%E2%80%9399-155)[\[144\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown199483-156)[\[145\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPeers200650-157) However, disaffection with the company also grew during this time and set off the [Indian Rebellion of 1857](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Rebellion_of_1857 "Indian Rebellion of 1857"). Fed by diverse resentments and perceptions, including invasive British-style social reforms, harsh land taxes, and summary treatment of some rich landowners and princes, the rebellion rocked many regions of northern and central India and shook the foundations of Company rule.[\[146\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006100%E2%80%93103-158)[\[147\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown199485%E2%80%9386-159) Although the rebellion was suppressed by 1858, it led to the dissolution of the East India Company and the [direct administration of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj") by the British government. Proclaiming a [unitary state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unitary_state "Unitary state") and a gradual but limited British-style parliamentary system, the new rulers also protected princes and landed gentry as a feudal safeguard against future unrest.[\[148\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998239-160)[\[149\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006103%E2%80%93108-161) In the decades following, public life gradually emerged all over India, leading eventually to the founding of the [Indian National Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress "Indian National Congress") in 1885.[\[150\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobb2001183-162)[\[151\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarkar19831%E2%80%934-163)[\[152\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECopland2001ix%E2%80%93x-164)[\[153\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006123-165) The rush of technology and the commercialisation of agriculture in the second half of the 19th century was marked by economic setbacks, and many small farmers became dependent on the whims of far-away markets.[\[154\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998260-166) There was an increase in the number of large-scale [famines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Famine_in_India "Famine in India"),[\[155\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein2010245-167) and, despite the risks of infrastructure development borne by Indian taxpayers, little industrial employment was generated for Indians.[\[156\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStein1998258-168) There were also salutary effects: commercial cropping, especially in the newly canalled Punjab, led to increased food production for internal consumption.[\[157\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006126-169) The railway network provided critical famine relief,[\[158\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200697-170) notably reduced the cost of moving goods,[\[158\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf200697-170) and helped nascent Indian-owned industry.[\[157\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006126-169) After [World War I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), in which approximately [one million Indians served](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Army_during_World_War_I "Indian Army during World War I"),[\[159\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006163-171) a new period began. It was marked by [British reforms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montagu%E2%80%93Chelmsford_Reforms "Montagu–Chelmsford Reforms") but also [repressive legislation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rowlatt_act "Rowlatt act"), by more strident Indian calls for self-rule, and by the beginnings of a [nonviolent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonviolent "Nonviolent") movement of non-co-operation, of which [Mahatma Gandhi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi "Mahatma Gandhi") would become the leader and enduring symbol.[\[160\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006167-172) During the 1930s, slow legislative reform was enacted by the British; the Indian National Congress won victories in the resulting elections.[\[161\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006195%E2%80%93197-173) The next decade was beset with crises: [Indian participation in World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India_in_World_War_II "India in World War II"), the Congress's final push for non-co-operation, and an upsurge of [Muslim nationalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslim_nationalism_in_South_Asia "Muslim nationalism in South Asia"). All were capped by the advent of independence in 1947, but tempered by the [partition of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partition_of_India "Partition of India") into two states: India and Pakistan.[\[162\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006203-174) Vital to India's self-image as an independent nation was its constitution, completed in 1950, which put in place a secular and democratic republic.[\[163\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006231-175) Economic liberalisation, which [began in the 1980s](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_liberalisation_in_India "Economic liberalisation in India") and with the collaboration with Soviet Union for technical knowledge,[\[164\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-176) has created a large urban middle class, transformed India into [one of the world's fastest-growing economies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(real)_growth_rate "List of countries by GDP (real) growth rate"),[\[165\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-177) and increased its geopolitical influence. Yet, India is also shaped by persistent poverty, both rural and urban;[\[166\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006265%E2%80%93266-178) by [religious](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religious_violence_in_India "Religious violence in India") and [caste-related violence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caste-related_violence_in_India "Caste-related violence in India");[\[167\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006266%E2%80%93270-179) by [Maoist-inspired Naxalite insurgencies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naxalite%E2%80%93Maoist_insurgency "Naxalite–Maoist insurgency");[\[168\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006253-180) and by [separatism in Jammu and Kashmir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insurgency_in_Jammu_and_Kashmir "Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir") and [in Northeast India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insurgency_in_Northeast_India "Insurgency in Northeast India").[\[169\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006274-181) It has unresolved territorial disputes with [China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China%E2%80%93India_relations#1960s "China–India relations") and with [Pakistan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_wars_and_conflicts "Indo-Pakistani wars and conflicts").[\[170\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006247%E2%80%93248-182) India's sustained democratic freedoms are unique among the world's newer nations; however, in spite of its recent economic successes, freedom from want for its disadvantaged population remains a goal yet to be achieved.[\[171\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMetcalfMetcalf2006304-183) ## Geography Main article: [Geography of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geography_of_India "Geography of India") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG/500px-Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Tungabhadra_River_and_Coracle_Boats.JPG) The [Tungabhadra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tungabhadra_River "Tungabhadra River"), with rocky outcrops, flows into the peninsular [Krishna River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krishna_River "Krishna River")[\[172\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcgrailBlueKentleyPalmer2003257-184)[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg/500px-Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Parked_boats_at_Anjarle_Creek.jpg) Fishing boats lashed together in a [tidal creek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Creek_(tidal) "Creek (tidal)") in [Anjarle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anjarle "Anjarle") village, Maharashtra India accounts for the bulk of the Indian subcontinent, lying atop the [Indian tectonic plate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Plate "Indian Plate"), a part of the [Indo-Australian Plate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Australian_Plate "Indo-Australian Plate").[\[173\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005-185) India's defining geological processes began 75 million years ago when the Indian Plate, then part of the southern supercontinent [Gondwana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gondwana "Gondwana"), began a north-eastward [drift](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plate_tectonics "Plate tectonics") caused by [seafloor spreading](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seafloor_spreading "Seafloor spreading") to its south-west, and later, south and south-east.[\[173\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005-185) Simultaneously, the vast [Tethyan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tethys_Ocean "Tethys Ocean") [oceanic crust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oceanic_crust "Oceanic crust"), to its northeast, began to [subduct](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subduction "Subduction") under the [Eurasian Plate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurasian_Plate "Eurasian Plate").[\[173\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005-185) These dual processes, driven by convection in the Earth's [mantle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mantle_(geology) "Mantle (geology)"), both created the Indian Ocean and caused the Indian [continental crust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continental_crust "Continental crust") eventually to under-thrust Eurasia and to uplift the [Himalayas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Himalayas "Himalayas").[\[173\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAliAitchison2005-185) Immediately south of the emerging Himalayas, plate movement created a vast crescent-shaped [trough](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trough_(geology) "Trough (geology)") that rapidly filled with river-borne sediment[\[174\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg20237-186) and now constitutes the [Indo-Gangetic Plain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Gangetic_Plain "Indo-Gangetic Plain").[\[175\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPrakash_et_al.2000-187) The original Indian plate makes its first appearance above the sediment in the ancient [Aravalli range](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aravalli_range "Aravalli range"), which extends from the [Delhi Ridge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi_Ridge "Delhi Ridge") in a southwesterly direction. To the west lies the [Thar Desert](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thar_Desert "Thar Desert"), the eastern spread of which is checked by the Aravallis.[\[176\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-aravalli-188)[\[177\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-prasad-aravalli-189)[\[178\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-fisher-aravalli-190) The remaining Indian Plate survives as [peninsular India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_India "South India"), the oldest and geologically most stable part of India. It extends as far north as the [Satpura](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satpura_Range "Satpura Range") and [Vindhya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vindhya_Range "Vindhya Range") ranges in central India. These parallel chains run from the Arabian Sea coast in Gujarat in the west to the coal-rich [Chota Nagpur Plateau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chota_Nagpur_Plateau "Chota Nagpur Plateau") in Jharkhand in the east.[\[179\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg20238-191) To the south, the remaining peninsular landmass, the [Deccan Plateau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deccan_Plateau "Deccan Plateau"), is flanked on the west and east by coastal ranges known as the [Western](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Ghats "Western Ghats") and [Eastern Ghats](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_Ghats "Eastern Ghats");[\[180\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg20239%E2%80%9310-192) the plateau contains the country's oldest rock formations, some over one billion years old. Constituted in such fashion, India lies to the north of the equator between 6° 44′ and 35° 30′ north latitude[\[m\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-193) and 68° 7′ and 97° 25′ east longitude.[\[181\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Information_and_Broadcasting20071-194) India's coastline measures 7,517 kilometres (4,700 mi) in length; of this distance, 5,423 kilometres (3,400 mi) belong to peninsular India and 2,094 kilometres (1,300 mi) to the Andaman, Nicobar, and Lakshadweep island chains.[\[182\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKumarPathakPednekarRaju2006-195) According to the Indian naval hydrographic charts, the [mainland coastline](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coastal_India "Coastal India") consists of the following: 43% sandy beaches; 11% rocky shores, including cliffs; and 46% [mudflats](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mudflat "Mudflat") or marshy shores.[\[182\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKumarPathakPednekarRaju2006-195) Major Himalayan-origin rivers that substantially flow through India include the [Ganges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ganges "Ganges") and the [Brahmaputra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brahmaputra_River "Brahmaputra River"), both of which drain into the [Bay of Bengal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bay_of_Bengal "Bay of Bengal").[\[183\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg202315-196) Important tributaries of the Ganges include the [Yamuna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yamuna "Yamuna") and the [Kosi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kosi_River "Kosi River"); the latter's extremely low gradient, caused by long-term silt deposition, leads to severe floods and course changes.[\[184\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDuff1993353-197)[\[185\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBasuXavier2017[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidnXmLDgAAQBAJpgPA78_78]-198) Major peninsular rivers, whose steeper gradients prevent their waters from flooding, include the [Godavari](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Godavari_River "Godavari River"), the [Mahanadi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mahanadi_River "Mahanadi River"), the [Kaveri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kaveri_River "Kaveri River"), and the [Krishna](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Krishna_River "Krishna River"), which also drain into the Bay of Bengal;[\[186\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg202316-199) and the [Narmada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narmada_River "Narmada River") and the [Tapti](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tapti_River "Tapti River"), which drain into the [Arabian Sea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arabian_Sea "Arabian Sea").[\[187\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg202317-200) Coastal features include the marshy [Rann of Kutch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rann_of_Kutch "Rann of Kutch") of western India and the alluvial [Sundarbans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sundarbans "Sundarbans") delta of eastern India; the latter is shared with Bangladesh.[\[188\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg202312-201) India has two [archipelagos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archipelago "Archipelago"): the [Lakshadweep](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakshadweep "Lakshadweep"), [coral atolls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atoll "Atoll") off India's south-western coast; and the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, a volcanic chain in the [Andaman Sea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andaman_Sea "Andaman Sea").[\[189\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDikshitSchwartzberg202313-202) [Indian climate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_of_India "Climate of India") is strongly influenced by the Himalayas and the Thar Desert, both of which drive the economically and culturally pivotal summer and winter [monsoons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monsoon "Monsoon").[\[190\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChang1967391%E2%80%93394-203) The Himalayas prevent cold Central Asian [katabatic winds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katabatic_wind "Katabatic wind") from blowing in, keeping the bulk of the Indian subcontinent warmer than most locations at similar latitudes.[\[191\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPosey1994118-204)[\[192\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWolpert20034-205) The Thar Desert plays a crucial role in attracting the moisture-laden south-west summer monsoon winds that, between June and October, provide the majority of India's rainfall.[\[190\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChang1967391%E2%80%93394-203) Four major climatic groupings predominate in India: [tropical wet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_of_India#Tropical_wet "Climate of India"), [tropical dry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_of_India#Arid_and_semi-arid_regions "Climate of India"), [subtropical humid](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_of_India#Subtropical_humid "Climate of India"), and [montane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_of_India#Mountain "Climate of India").[\[193\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeitzmanWorden199697-206) Temperatures in India have risen by 0.7 °C (1.3 °F) between 1901 and 2018.[\[194\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-207) [Climate change in India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_change_in_India "Climate change in India") is often thought to be the cause. The [retreat of Himalayan glaciers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Retreat_of_glaciers_since_1850 "Retreat of glaciers since 1850") has adversely affected the [flow rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volumetric_flow_rate "Volumetric flow rate") of the major Himalayan rivers, including the [Ganges](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ganges "Ganges") and the [Brahmaputra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brahmaputra "Brahmaputra").[\[195\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-208) According to some current projections, the number and severity of droughts in India will have markedly increased by the end of the present century.[\[196\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-209) ### Biodiversity Main articles: [Forestry in India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forestry_in_India "Forestry in India") and [Wildlife of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildlife_of_India "Wildlife of India") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg/500px-Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Panthera_tigris_tigris_Tidoba_20150306.jpg) India has the majority of the world's wild [tigers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiger "Tiger"), approximately 3,170 in 2022.[\[197\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-210)[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Axis_axis_%28Nagarhole%2C_2010%29.jpg/500px-Axis_axis_%28Nagarhole%2C_2010%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Axis_axis_(Nagarhole,_2010).jpg) A [chital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chital "Chital") ( _Axis axis_) stag in the [Nagarhole National Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nagarhole_National_Park "Nagarhole National Park") in a region covered by a moderately dense[\[n\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-211) forest.[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Maharajah_Ramanuj_Pratap_Singh_Deo_with_cheetah_kill_1948_BNHS.jpg/500px-Maharajah_Ramanuj_Pratap_Singh_Deo_with_cheetah_kill_1948_BNHS.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Maharajah_Ramanuj_Pratap_Singh_Deo_with_cheetah_kill_1948_BNHS.jpg) Three of the last [Asiatic cheetahs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asiatic_cheetah "Asiatic cheetah") in India were shot dead in 1948 in [Surguja district](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surguja_district "Surguja district"), [Madhya Pradesh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh "Madhya Pradesh"), [Central India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_India "Central India") by Maharajah [Ramanuj Pratap Singh Deo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramanuj_Pratap_Singh_Deo "Ramanuj Pratap Singh Deo"). The young male [cheetahs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cheetah "Cheetah"), all from the same litter, were sitting together when they were shot at night. India is a [megadiverse country](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megadiverse_country "Megadiverse country"), a term employed for 17 countries that display high [biological diversity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_diversity "Biological diversity") and contain many species exclusively [indigenous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indigenous_(ecology) "Indigenous (ecology)"), or [endemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endemic "Endemic"), to them.[\[198\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-212) India is the [habitat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Habitat "Habitat") for 8.6% of all [mammals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mammal "Mammal"), 13.7% of [bird](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bird "Bird") species, 7.9% of [reptile](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reptile "Reptile") species, 6% of [amphibian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amphibian "Amphibian") species, 12.2% of [fish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fish "Fish") species, and 6.0% of all [flowering plant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flowering_plant "Flowering plant") species.[\[199\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-213)[\[200\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Puri-214) Fully a third of Indian plant species are endemic.[\[201\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBasak198324-215) India also contains four of the world's 34 [biodiversity hotspots](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_hotspot "Biodiversity hotspot"),[\[71\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-IUCN-India-83) or regions that display significant habitat loss in the presence of high endemism.[\[o\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-217)[\[202\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-SivaperumanVenkataraman2018-216) India's most dense forests, such as the [tropical moist forest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_moist_broadleaf_forest "Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forest") of the [Andaman Islands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andaman_Islands "Andaman Islands"), the [Western Ghats](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Ghats "Western Ghats"), and [Northeast India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_India "Northeast India"), occupy approximately 3% of its land area.[\[203\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Jha2018-218)[\[204\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-indiaforest-219) _Moderately dense forest_, whose canopy density is between 40% and 70%, occupies 9.39% of India's land area.[\[203\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Jha2018-218)[\[204\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-indiaforest-219) It predominates in the [temperate coniferous forest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temperate_coniferous_forest "Temperate coniferous forest") of the [Himalayas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Himalaya "Himalaya"), the moist deciduous _[sal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shorea_robusta "Shorea robusta")_ forest of eastern India, and the dry deciduous [teak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teak "Teak") forest of central and southern India.[\[205\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTETritsch200111%E2%80%9312-220) India has two natural zones of [thorn forest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deserts_and_xeric_shrublands "Deserts and xeric shrublands"), one in the [Deccan Plateau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deccan_Plateau "Deccan Plateau"), immediately east of the Western Ghats, and the other in the western part of the Indo-Gangetic plain, now turned into rich agricultural land by irrigation, its features no longer visible.[\[206\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTETritsch200112-221) Among the Indian subcontinent's notable indigenous trees are the [astringent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astringent "Astringent") _[Azadirachta indica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azadirachta_indica "Azadirachta indica")_, or _neem_, which is widely used in rural Indian [herbal medicine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbal_medicine "Herbal medicine"),[\[207\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Goyal2006-222) and the luxuriant _[Ficus religiosa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ficus_religiosa "Ficus religiosa")_, or _peepul_,[\[208\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Hughes2013-223) which is displayed on the ancient seals of [Mohenjo-daro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohenjo-daro "Mohenjo-daro"),[\[209\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-AmeriCostello2018-224) and under which [the Buddha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gautama_Buddha "Gautama Buddha") is recorded in the [Pali canon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P%C4%81li_Canon "Pāli Canon") to have sought enlightenment.[\[210\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Gwynne2011-225) Many Indian species have descended from those of [Gondwana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gondwana "Gondwana"), the southern [supercontinent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supercontinent "Supercontinent") from which India separated more than 100 million years ago.[\[211\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrameOwen2002142-226) India's subsequent collision with Eurasia set off a mass exchange of species. However, [volcanism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deccan_Traps "Deccan Traps") and [climatic changes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_variability_and_change "Climate variability and change") later caused the extinction of many endemic Indian forms.[\[212\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKaranth2006-227) Still later, mammals entered India from Asia through two [zoogeographic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zoogeography "Zoogeography") passes flanking the Himalayas.[\[213\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTETritsch200114-228) This had the effect of lowering endemism among India's mammals, which stands at 12.6%, contrasting with 45.8% among reptiles and 55.8% among amphibians.[\[200\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Puri-214) Among endemics are the vulnerable[\[214\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-229) [hooded leaf monkey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nilgiri_Langur "Nilgiri Langur")[\[215\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-itis-230) and the threatened [Beddome's toad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duttaphrynus_beddomii "Duttaphrynus beddomii")[\[216\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-IUCN-231)[\[217\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-232) of the Western Ghats. India contains 172 [IUCN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Conservation_Union "World Conservation Union")-designated [threatened animal species](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_endangered_animals_in_India "List of endangered animals in India"), or 2.9% of endangered forms.[\[218\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMace19944-233) These include the endangered [Bengal tiger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bengal_tiger "Bengal tiger") and the [Ganges river dolphin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Asian_river_dolphin "South Asian river dolphin"). [Critically endangered](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critically_endangered "Critically endangered") species include the [gharial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gharial "Gharial"), a [crocodilian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crocodilian "Crocodilian"); the [great Indian bustard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Indian_bustard "Great Indian bustard"); and the [Indian white-rumped vulture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White-rumped_vulture "White-rumped vulture"), which has become nearly extinct by having ingested the carrion of [diclofenac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diclofenac "Diclofenac")-treated cattle.[\[219\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-LovetteFitzpatrick2016-234) Before they were extensively used for agriculture and cleared for human settlement, the thorn forests of Punjab were mingled at intervals with open grasslands that were grazed by large herds of [blackbuck](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blackbuck_Conservation_Area "Blackbuck Conservation Area") preyed on by the [Asiatic cheetah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asiatic_cheetah "Asiatic cheetah"); the blackbuck, no longer extant in Punjab, is now severely endangered in India, and the cheetah is extinct.[\[220\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTETritsch200115-235) The pervasive and ecologically devastating human encroachment of recent decades has critically endangered Indian wildlife. In response, the system of [national parks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_parks_of_India "National parks of India") and [protected areas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protected_areas_of_India "Protected areas of India"), first established in 1935, was expanded substantially. In 1972, India enacted the [Wildlife Protection Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildlife_Protection_Act_of_1972 "Wildlife Protection Act of 1972")[\[221\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Environment_and_Forests_1972-236) and [Project Tiger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_Tiger "Project Tiger") to safeguard crucial wilderness; the Forest Conservation Act was enacted in 1980 and amendments added in 1988.[\[222\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDepartment_of_Environment_and_Forests1988-237) India hosts [more than five hundred wildlife sanctuaries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildlife_sanctuaries_of_India "Wildlife sanctuaries of India") and [eighteenbiosphere reserves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biosphere_reserves_of_India "Biosphere reserves of India"),[\[223\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-238) four of which are part of the [World Network of Biosphere Reserves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Network_of_Biosphere_Reserves "World Network of Biosphere Reserves"); its [eighty-nine wetlands](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Ramsar_sites_in_India "List of Ramsar sites in India") are registered under the [Ramsar Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramsar_Convention "Ramsar Convention").[\[224\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-239) ## Politics and government ### Politics Main article: [Politics of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politics_of_India "Politics of India") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Rajagopal_speaking_to_25%2C000_people%2C_Janadesh_2007%2C_India.jpg/500px-Rajagopal_speaking_to_25%2C000_people%2C_Janadesh_2007%2C_India.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Rajagopal_speaking_to_25,000_people,_Janadesh_2007,_India.jpg) As part of [Janadesh 2007](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janadesh_2007 "Janadesh 2007"), 25,000 pro– [land reform](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Land_reform_in_India "Land reform in India") [landless](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landless "Landless") people in [Madhya Pradesh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh "Madhya Pradesh") listen to [Rajagopal P. V.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajagopal_P._V. "Rajagopal P. V.")[\[225\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Johnston2019-240)[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg/500px-Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_at_Parliament_of_India_in_New_Delhi_addressing_Joint_session_of_both_houses_2010.jpg) US president [Barack Obama](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama") addresses the [members](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Member_of_Parliament_(India) "Member of Parliament (India)") of the [Parliament of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_India "Parliament of India") in [New Delhi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Delhi "New Delhi") in November 2010.
