India is a [parliamentary republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliamentary_republic "Parliamentary republic") with a [multi-party system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-party_system "Multi-party system").[\[226\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurnellCalvert1999125-241) It has sixrecognised [national parties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_India#National_parties "List of political parties in India"), including the [Indian National Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_National_Congress "Indian National Congress") (INC) and the [Bharatiya Janata Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bharatiya_Janata_Party "Bharatiya Janata Party") (BJP), and over 50 [regional parties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_India#State_parties "List of political parties in India").[\[227\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElection_Commission_of_India-242) Congress is considered the [ideological centre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centrism "Centrism") in Indian [political culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_culture "Political culture"),[\[228\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-243) whereas the BJP is [right-wing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right-wing_politics "Right-wing politics").[\[229\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMalikSingh1992318%E2%80%93336-244)[\[230\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBanerjee20053118-245)[\[231\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-246) From 1950 to the late 1980s, Congress held a majority in the [India's parliament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_India "Parliament of India"). Afterwards, it increasingly shared power with the BJP,[\[232\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESarkar200784-247) as well as with powerful regional parties, which forced multi-party [coalition governments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coalition_government "Coalition government") at the centre.[\[233\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChander2004117-248) In the [Republic of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_India "Republic of India")'s general elections in [1951](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1951_Indian_general_election "1951 Indian general election"), [1957](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1957_Indian_general_election "1957 Indian general election"), and [1962](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1962_Indian_general_election "1962 Indian general election"), Congress, led by [Jawaharlal Nehru](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru "Jawaharlal Nehru"), won easy victories. On Nehru's death in 1964, [Lal Bahadur Shastri](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lal_Bahadur_Shastri "Lal Bahadur Shastri") briefly became prime minister; he was succeeded in 1966, by Nehru's daughter [Indira Gandhi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indira_Gandhi "Indira Gandhi"), who led the Congress to election victories in [1967](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1967_Indian_general_election "1967 Indian general election") and [1971](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1971_Indian_general_election "1971 Indian general election"). Following public discontent with the [state of emergency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Emergency_(India) "The Emergency (India)") Indira Gandhi had declared in 1975, Congress was voted out of power in [1977](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1977_Indian_general_election "1977 Indian general election"); [Janata Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janata_Party "Janata Party"), which had opposed the emergency, was voted in. Its government lasted two years; [Morarji Desai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morarji_Desai "Morarji Desai") and [Charan Singh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charan_Singh "Charan Singh") served as prime ministers. After Congress was returned to power in 1980, Indira Gandhi was [assassinated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_Indira_Gandhi "Assassination of Indira Gandhi") and succeeded by [Rajiv Gandhi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajiv_Gandhi "Rajiv Gandhi"), who won easily in the elections [later that year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1984_Indian_general_election "1984 Indian general election"). In the [1989 elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1989_Indian_general_election "1989 Indian general election") a [National Front](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Front_(India) "National Front (India)") coalition, led by the [Janata Dal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Janata_Dal "Janata Dal") in alliance with the [Left Front](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Party_of_India_(Marxist) "Communist Party of India (Marxist)"), won, lasting just under two years, and [V.P. Singh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V.P._Singh "V.P. Singh") and [Chandra Shekhar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chandra_Shekhar "Chandra Shekhar") serving as prime ministers.[\[234\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhambhri1992118,_143-249) In the [1991 Indian general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1991_Indian_general_election "1991 Indian general election"), Congress, as the largest single party, formed a [minority government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minority_government "Minority government") led by [P. V. Narasimha Rao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P._V._Narasimha_Rao "P. V. Narasimha Rao").[\[235\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-250) After the [1996 Indian general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1996_Indian_general_election "1996 Indian general election"), the BJP formed a government briefly; it was followed by [United Front](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Front_(India,_1996) "United Front (India, 1996)") coalitions, which depended on external political support. Two prime ministers served during this period: [H.D. Deve Gowda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H.D._Deve_Gowda "H.D. Deve Gowda") and [I.K. Gujral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I.K._Gujral "I.K. Gujral"). In [1998](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1998_Indian_general_election "1998 Indian general election"), the BJP formed a coalition—the [National Democratic Alliance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance "National Democratic Alliance") (NDA). Led by [Atal Bihari Vajpayee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atal_Bihari_Vajpayee "Atal Bihari Vajpayee"), the NDA became the first non-Congress, [coalition government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coalition_government "Coalition government") to complete a five-year term.[\[236\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDunleavyDiwakarDunleavy2007-251) In the [2004 Indian general elections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2004_Indian_general_election "2004 Indian general election"), no party won an absolute majority. Still, the Congress emerged as the largest single party, forming another successful coalition: the [United Progressive Alliance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Progressive_Alliance "United Progressive Alliance") (UPA). It had the support of [left-leaning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Left-wing_politics "Left-wing politics") parties and MPs who opposed the BJP. The UPA returned to power in the [2009 general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2009_Indian_general_election "2009 Indian general election") with increased numbers, and it no longer required external support from [India's communist parties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Communist_Parties_in_India "List of Communist Parties in India").[\[237\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKulkeRothermund2004384-252) [Manmohan Singh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manmohan_Singh "Manmohan Singh") became the first prime minister since [Jawaharlal Nehru](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru "Jawaharlal Nehru") in [1957](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1957_Indian_general_election "1957 Indian general election") and [1962](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1962_Indian_general_election "1962 Indian general election") to be re-elected to a consecutive five-year term.[\[238\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBusiness_Standard2009-253) In the [2014 general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Indian_general_election "2014 Indian general election"), the BJP became the first political party since 1984 to win an absolute majority.[\[239\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-254) In the [2019 general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Indian_general_election "2019 Indian general election"), the BJP regained an absolute majority. In the [2024 general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Indian_general_election "2024 Indian general election"), a BJP-led NDA coalition [formed the government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third_Modi_ministry "Third Modi ministry"). [Narendra Modi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narendra_Modi "Narendra Modi"), a former [chief minister](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_minister_(India) "Chief minister (India)") of [Gujarat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gujarat "Gujarat"), is serving as the prime minister of India in his third term since May 26, 2014.[\[240\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-255) ### Government Main articles: [Government of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Government_of_India "Government of India") and [Constitution of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_India "Constitution of India") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg/500px-Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Rashtrapati_Bhavan_Wide_New_Delhi_India.jpg) [Rashtrapati Bhavan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rashtrapati_Bhavan "Rashtrapati Bhavan"), the official residence of the [President of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_India "President of India"), was designed by British architects [Edwin Lutyens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edwin_Lutyens "Edwin Lutyens") and [Herbert Baker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_Baker "Herbert Baker") for the [Viceroy of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viceroy_of_India "Viceroy of India"), and constructed between 1911 and 1931 during the [British Raj](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Raj "British Raj").[\[241\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Bremner2016-256) India is a [federation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federation "Federation") with a [parliamentary system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliamentary_system "Parliamentary system") governed under the [Constitution of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_India "Constitution of India"). [Federalism in India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federalism_in_India "Federalism in India") defines the power distribution between the union and the [states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_and_territories_of_India "States and territories of India"). India's form of government, traditionally described as "quasi-federal" with a strong centre and weak states,[\[242\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWheare198028-257) has grown increasingly federal since the late 1990s as a result of political, economic, and social changes.[\[243\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEcheverri-Gent200219%E2%80%9320-258)[\[244\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESinha200425-259) The Government of India comprises three branches: the [Executive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_(government) "Executive (government)"), [Legislature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legislature "Legislature"), and [Judiciary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judiciary "Judiciary").[\[245\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-260) The [President of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_India "President of India") is the ceremonial [head of state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_of_state "Head of state"),[\[246\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200731-261) who is elected indirectly for a five-year term by an [electoral college](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electoral_College_(India) "Electoral College (India)") comprising members of national and state legislatures.[\[247\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007138-262)[\[248\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGledhill1970112-263) The [Prime Minister of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_India "Prime Minister of India") is the [head of government](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_of_government "Head of government") and exercises most [executive power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_(government) "Executive (government)").[\[249\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma1950-264) Appointed by the president,[\[250\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007162-265) the prime minister is supported by the [party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_party "Political party") or [political alliance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_alliance "Political alliance") with a majority of seats in the lower house of parliament.[\[249\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma1950-264) The executive of the Indian government consists of the president, the [vice-president](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_President_of_India "Vice President of India"), and the [Union Council of Ministers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_Council_of_Ministers "Union Council of Ministers")—with the [cabinet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cabinet_(government) "Cabinet (government)") being its executive committee—headed by the prime minister. Any minister holding a portfolio must be a member of one of the houses of parliament.[\[246\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200731-261) In the Indian parliamentary system, the executive is subordinate to the legislature; the prime minister and their council are directly responsible to the lower house of the parliament. [Civil servants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_Services_of_India "Civil Services of India") act as permanent executives and all decisions of the [executive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Executive_(government) "Executive (government)") are implemented by them.[\[251\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMathew2003524-266) The legislature of India is the [bicameral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bicameralism "Bicameralism") [parliament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_India "Parliament of India"). Operating under a [Westminster-style](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westminster_system "Westminster system") parliamentary system, it comprises an upper house called the [Rajya Sabha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajya_Sabha "Rajya Sabha") (Council of States) and a lower house called the [Lok Sabha](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lok_Sabha "Lok Sabha") (House of the People).[\[252\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGledhill1970127-267) The Rajya Sabha is a permanent body of 245members who serve staggered six-year terms with elections every 2 years.[\[253\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007161-268) Most are elected indirectly by the [state and union territorial](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_and_union_territories_of_India "States and union territories of India") legislatures in numbers proportional to their state's share of the national population.[\[250\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007162-265) The Lok Sabha's 543members are elected directly by popular vote among citizens aged at least 18;[\[254\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMadhavan202417%E2%80%9318-269) they represent [single-member constituencies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single-member_constituency "Single-member constituency") for five-yearterms.[\[255\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007143-270) Several seats from each state are reserved for candidates from [Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scheduled_Castes_and_Scheduled_Tribes "Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes") in proportion to their population within that state.[\[254\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMadhavan202417%E2%80%9318-269) India has a three-tierunitary [independent judiciary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judicial_independence "Judicial independence")[\[256\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeuborne2003478-271) comprising the [supreme court](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_India "Supreme Court of India"), headed by the [Chief Justice of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_India "Chief Justice of India"), 25 [high courts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_courts_of_India "High courts of India"), and a large number of trial courts.[\[256\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTENeuborne2003478-271) The supreme court has [original jurisdiction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Original_jurisdiction "Original jurisdiction") over cases involving [fundamental rights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fundamental_rights_in_India "Fundamental rights in India") and over disputes between states and the centre and has [appellate jurisdiction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Appellate_jurisdiction "Appellate jurisdiction") over the high courts.[\[257\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2007238,_255-272) It has the power to both strike down union or state laws which contravene the constitution[\[258\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESripati1998423%E2%80%93424-273) and invalidate any government action it deems unconstitutional.[\[259\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPylee2003b314-274) ### Administrative divisions Main article: [Administrative divisions of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_India "Administrative divisions of India") See also: [Political integration of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_integration_of_India "Political integration of India") ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Political_map_of_India_EN.svg/500px-Political_map_of_India_EN.svg.png)A clickable map of the 28 states and 8 union territories of India India is a federal union comprising 28 [states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_and_union_territories_of_India "States and union territories of India") and 8 [union territories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_territory "Union territory").[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTELibrary_of_Congress2004-19) All states, as well as the union territories of [Jammu and Kashmir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jammu_and_Kashmir_(union_territory) "Jammu and Kashmir (union territory)"), [Puducherry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puducherry_(union_territory) "Puducherry (union territory)") and the [National Capital Territory of Delhi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi "Delhi"), have elected legislatures and governments following the [Westminster system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westminster_system "Westminster system"). The remaining five union territories are directly ruled by the central government through appointed administrators. In 1956, under the [States Reorganisation Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_Reorganisation_Act,_1956 "States Reorganisation Act, 1956"), states were reorganised on a linguistic basis.[\[260\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200749-275) There are over a quarter of a million local government bodies at city, town, block, district and village levels.[\[261\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-276) #### States 01. [Puducherry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puducherry_(union_territory) "Puducherry (union territory)") ## Foreign, economic, and strategic relations Main articles: [Foreign relations of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_India "Foreign relations of India") and [Indian Armed Forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Armed_Forces "Indian Armed Forces") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Jawaharlal_Nehru%2C_Nasser_and_Tito_at_the_Conference_of_Non-Aligned_Nations_held_in_Belgrade.jpg/500px-Jawaharlal_Nehru%2C_Nasser_and_Tito_at_the_Conference_of_Non-Aligned_Nations_held_in_Belgrade.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Jawaharlal_Nehru,_Nasser_and_Tito_at_the_Conference_of_Non-Aligned_Nations_held_in_Belgrade.jpg) During the 1950s and 60s, India played a pivotal role in the [Non-Aligned Movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement "Non-Aligned Movement").[\[262\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Dinkel2018-277) From left to right: [Gamal Abdel Nasser](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamal_Abdel_Nasser "Gamal Abdel Nasser") of [United Arab Republic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Arab_Republic "United Arab Republic") (now Egypt), [Josip Broz Tito](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito "Josip Broz Tito") of [Yugoslavia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia") and [Jawaharlal Nehru](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jawaharlal_Nehru "Jawaharlal Nehru") in Belgrade, September 1961. India became a republic in 1950, remaining a member of the [Commonwealth of Nations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations").[\[263\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-storm-india-commonwealth-278)[\[264\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-279) India strongly supported decolonisation in Africa and Asia in the 1950s; it played a leading role in the Non-Aligned Movement.[\[265\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTERothermund200048,_227-280) After cordial relations initially, India went to [war with China in 1962](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sino-Indian_War "Sino-Indian War"). India was widely thought to have been humiliated.[\[266\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-62-humiliation-281) Another [military conflict followed in 1967](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nathu_La_and_Cho_La_clashes "Nathu La and Cho La clashes") in which India successfully repelled a Chinese attack.[\[267\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-282) India has had [uneasy relations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_relations "Indo-Pakistani relations") with its western neighbour, Pakistan. The two countries went to war in [1947](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1947 "Indo-Pakistani War of 1947"), [1965](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1965 "Indo-Pakistani War of 1965"), [1971](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Pakistani_War_of_1971 "Indo-Pakistani War of 1971"), and [1999](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kargil_War "Kargil War"). Three of these wars were fought over the [disputed territory of Kashmir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kashmir_conflict "Kashmir conflict"). In contrast, the 1971 war followed India's support for the [independence of Bangladesh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangladesh_Liberation_War "Bangladesh Liberation War").[\[268\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGilbert2002486%E2%80%93487-283) After the 1965 war with Pakistan, India began to pursue close military and economic [ties with the Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India-Soviet_Union_relations "India-Soviet Union relations"); by the late 1960s, the Soviet Union was its largest arms supplier.[\[269\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma199956-284) India has played a key role in the [South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Asian_Association_for_Regional_Cooperation "South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation") and the [World Trade Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Trade_Organization "World Trade Organization"). The nation has supplied 100,000 [military](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Armed_Forces "Indian Armed Forces") and [police](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_India "Law enforcement in India") personnel in 35 [UN peacekeeping operations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_peacekeeping "United Nations peacekeeping").\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\] [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Indian_Air_Force_contingent_as_a_part_of_the_Bastille_Day_Parade_of_France%2C_in_Paris_on_July_14%2C_2009.jpg/500px-Indian_Air_Force_contingent_as_a_part_of_the_Bastille_Day_Parade_of_France%2C_in_Paris_on_July_14%2C_2009.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Indian_Air_Force_contingent_as_a_part_of_the_Bastille_Day_Parade_of_France,_in_Paris_on_July_14,_2009.jpg) The [Indian Air Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Air_Force "Indian Air Force") contingent marching at the 221st [Bastille Day military parade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bastille_Day_military_parade "Bastille Day military parade") in Paris, on 14 July 2009. The parade at which India was the foreign guest was led by India's oldest regiment, the [Maratha Light Infantry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maratha_Light_Infantry "Maratha Light Infantry"), founded in 1768.[\[270\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-guardian-muir-diary-maratha-285) China's [nuclear test of 1964](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/596_(nuclear_test) "596 (nuclear test)") and threats to intervene in support of Pakistan in the 1965 war caused India to produce nuclear weapons.[\[271\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPerkovich200160%E2%80%9386,_106%E2%80%93125-286) India conducted its [first nuclear weapons test](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smiling_Buddha "Smiling Buddha") in 1974 and carried out [additional underground testing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pokhran-II "Pokhran-II") in 1998. India has signed neither the [Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comprehensive_Nuclear-Test-Ban_Treaty "Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty") nor the [Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_Non-Proliferation_Treaty "Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty"), considering both to be flawed and discriminatory.[\[272\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKumar2010-287) India maintains a " [no first use](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/No_first_use "No first use")" nuclear policy and is developing a [nuclear triad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_triad "Nuclear triad") capability as a part of its " [Minimum Credible Deterrence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_Credible_Deterrence "Minimum Credible Deterrence")" doctrine.[\[273\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTENair2007-288)[\[274\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPandit2009-289) Since the end of the [Cold War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"), India has increased its economic, strategic, and military cooperation with the [United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India%E2%80%93United_States_relations "India–United States relations") and the [European Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India%E2%80%93European_Union_relations "India–European Union relations").[\[275\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEuropean_Union_2008-290) In 2008, a [civilian nuclear agreement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S.%E2%80%93India_Civil_Nuclear_Agreement "U.S.–India Civil Nuclear Agreement") was signed between India and the United States. Although India possessed nuclear weapons at the time and was not a party to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, it received waivers from the [International Atomic Energy Agency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency "International Atomic Energy Agency") and the [Nuclear Suppliers Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_Suppliers_Group "Nuclear Suppliers Group"), ending earlier restrictions on India's nuclear technology and commerce; India subsequently signed co-operation agreements involving [civilian nuclear energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_India "Nuclear power in India") with Russia,[\[276\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBritish_Broadcasting_Corporation_2009-291) France,[\[277\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTERediff_2008_a-292) the [United Kingdom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India%E2%80%93United_Kingdom_relations "India–United Kingdom relations"),[\[278\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEReuters2010-293) and [Canada](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93India_relations "Canada–India relations").[\[279\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurry2010-294) The President of India is the supreme commander of the nation's armed forces; with 1.45 million active troops, they compose the [world's second-largest military](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_number_of_troops "List of countries by number of troops"). It comprises the [Indian Army](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Army "Indian Army"), the [Indian Navy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Navy "Indian Navy"), the [Indian Air Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Air_Force "Indian Air Force"), and the [Indian Coast Guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_Coast_Guard "Indian Coast Guard").[\[280\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECentral_Intelligence_Agency-295) The official Indian [defence budget](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures "List of countries by military expenditures") for 2011 was US$36.03 billion, or 1.83% of GDP.[\[281\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBehera2011-296) Defence expenditure was pegged at US$70.12 billion for fiscal year 2022–23 and, increased 9.8% than previous fiscal year.[\[282\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-297)[\[283\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPandit2022-298) India is the world's second-largest arms importer; between 2016 and 2020, it accounted for 9.5% of the total global arms imports.[\[284\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPandit2021-299) Much of the military expenditure was focused on defence against Pakistan and countering growing Chinese influence in the Indian Ocean.[\[285\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiglani2011-300) ## Economy Main article: [Economy of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_India "Economy of India") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Plowing_the_land_in_India_-_modern_and_traditional.jpg/500px-Plowing_the_land_in_India_-_modern_and_traditional.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Plowing_the_land_in_India_-_modern_and_traditional.jpg) In 2019, 43% of India's total workforce was employed in agriculture.[\[286\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-worldbank-ilo-total-agriculture-301) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/ILRI%2C_Stevie_Mann_-_Villager_and_calf_share_milk_from_cow_in_Rajasthan%2C_India.jpg/500px-ILRI%2C_Stevie_Mann_-_Villager_and_calf_share_milk_from_cow_in_Rajasthan%2C_India.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:ILRI,_Stevie_Mann_-_Villager_and_calf_share_milk_from_cow_in_Rajasthan,_India.jpg) India is the world's largest producer of milk, with the largest population of cattle. In 2018, nearly 80% of India's milk was sourced from small farms with herd size between one and two, the milk harvested by hand milking.[\[288\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-milk-sourcing-303) [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Women_at_work%2C_Gujarat_%28cropped%29.jpg/500px-Women_at_work%2C_Gujarat_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Women_at_work,_Gujarat_(cropped).jpg) 55% of India's female workforce was employed in agriculture in 2019.[\[287\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-worldbank-ilo-female-agriculture-302) According to the [International Monetary Fund](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund "International Monetary Fund") (IMF), the Indian economy in 2024 was nominally worth $3.94 trillion; it was the [fifth-largest economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal) "List of countries by GDP (nominal)") by market exchange rates and is, at around $15.0 trillion, the [third-largest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP) "List of countries by GDP (PPP)") by [purchasing power parity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity "Purchasing power parity") (PPP).[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-IMFWEO.IN-24) With its average annual GDP growth rate of 5.8% over the past two decades, and reaching 6.1% during 2011–2012,[\[289\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund_20112-304) India is one of the [world's fastest-growing economies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_real_GDP_growth_rate "List of countries by real GDP growth rate").[\[290\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTENayakGoldarAgrawal2010xxv-305) However, due to its low GDP per capita—which ranks 136th in the world in nominal per capita income and 125th in per capita income adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP)—the vast majority of Indians fall into the low-income group.[\[291\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Monetary_Fund-306)[\[292\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-307) Until 1991, all Indian governments followed [protectionist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protectionism "Protectionism") policies that were influenced by socialist economics. Widespread [state intervention and regulation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Licence_Raj "Licence Raj") largely walled the economy off from the outside world. An acute [balance of payments crisis in 1991](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1991_Indian_economic_crisis "1991 Indian economic crisis") forced the nation to [liberalise its economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_liberalisation_in_India "Economic liberalisation in India");[\[293\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWolpert2003xiv-308) since then, it has moved increasingly towards a free-market system[\[294\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOrganisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development_2007-309)[\[295\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGargan1992-310) by emphasising both foreign trade and direct investment inflows.[\[296\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlamgir200823,_97-311) India has been a member of [World Trade Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Trade_Organization "World Trade Organization") since 1 January 1995.[\[297\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWorld_Trade_Organization_1995-312) The 522-million-worker [Indian labour force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labour_in_India "Labour in India") is the [world's second largest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_labour_force "List of countries by labour force"), as of 2017[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=India&action=edit).[\[280\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECentral_Intelligence_Agency-295) The service sector makes up 55.6% of GDP, the industrial sector 26.3% and the agricultural sector 18.1%. India's [foreign exchange remittances](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remittance "Remittance") of US$100 billion in 2022,[\[298\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-313) highest in the world, were contributed to its economy by 32 million Indians working in foreign countries.[\[299\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-314) In 2006, the share of external trade in India's GDP stood at 24%, up from 6% in 1985.[\[294\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOrganisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development_2007-309) In 2008, India's share of world trade was 1.7%;[\[300\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-315) In 2021, India was the [world's ninth-largest importer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_imports "List of countries by imports") and the [sixteenth-largest exporter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports "List of countries by exports").[\[301\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-316) Between 2001 and 2011, the contribution of petrochemical and engineering goods to total exports grew from 14% to 42%.[\[302\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEconomist_2011-317) India was the world's second-largest textile exporter after [China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China "China") in the 2013 calendar year.[\[303\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEconomic_Times_2014-318) Averaging an economic growth rate of 7.5% for several years before 2007,[\[294\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOrganisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development_2007-309) India has more than doubled its hourly wage rates during the first decade of the 21st century.[\[304\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBonner2010-319) Some 431 million Indians have left poverty since 1985; India's middle classes are projected to number around 580 million by 2030.[\[305\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFarrellBeinhocker2007-320) In 2023, India's consumer market was the [world's fifth largest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_consumer_markets "List of largest consumer markets").[\[306\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-321) India's nominal [GDP per capita](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GDP_per_capita "GDP per capita") increased steadily from US$308 in 1991, when economic liberalisation began, to US$1,380 in 2010, to an estimated US$2,731 in 2024. It is expected to grow to US$3,264 by 2026.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-IMFWEO.IN-24) ### Industries [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Cherry_Resort_inside_Temi_Tea_Garden%2C_Namchi%2C_Sikkim.jpg/500px-Cherry_Resort_inside_Temi_Tea_Garden%2C_Namchi%2C_Sikkim.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Cherry_Resort_inside_Temi_Tea_Garden,_Namchi,_Sikkim.jpg) A tea garden in Sikkim. India, the world's second-largest producer of tea, is a nation of one billion tea drinkers, who consume 70% of India's tea output. The [Indian automotive industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_India "Automotive industry in India"), the world's second-fastest growing, increased domestic sales by 26% during 2009–2010,[\[307\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBusiness_Line_2010-322) and exports by 36% during 2008–2009.[\[308\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEExpress_India_2009-323) In 2022, India became the world's third-largest vehicle market after China and the United States, surpassing Japan.[\[309\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-324) At the end of 2011, the [Indian IT industry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_technology_in_India "Information technology in India") employed 2.8 million professionals, generated revenues close to US$100 billion equalling 7.5% of Indian GDP, and contributed 26% of India's merchandise exports.[\[310\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTENasscom_2011%E2%80%932012-325) The [pharmaceutical industry in India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pharmaceutical_industry_in_India "Pharmaceutical industry in India") includes 3,000 pharmaceutical companies and 10,500 manufacturing units; India is the world's third-largest pharmaceutical producer, largest producer of generic medicines and supply up to 50–60% of global vaccines demand, these all contribute up to US$24.44 billions in exports and India's local pharmaceutical market is estimated up to US$42 billion.[\[311\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Phamra1-326)[\[312\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Pharma2-327) India is among the top 12 biotech destinations in the world.[\[313\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-328)[\[314\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYep2011-329) The Indian biotech industry grew by 15.1% in 2012–2013, increasing its revenues from ₹204.4 billion ( [Indian rupees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_rupee "Indian rupee")) to ₹235.24 billion (US$3.94 billion at June 2013 exchange rates).[\[315\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-330) ### Energy Main articles: [Energy in India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_in_India "Energy in India") and [Energy policy of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_policy_of_India "Energy policy of India") India's capacity to generate electrical power is 300 gigawatts, of which 42 gigawatts is renewable.[\[316\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Par-331) [The country's usage of coal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coal_in_India "Coal in India") is a major cause of [India's greenhouse gas emissions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_change_in_India#Greenhouse_gas_emissions "Climate change in India"), but [its renewable energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_India "Renewable energy in India") is competing strongly.[\[317\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-332)\[ _[better source needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS "Wikipedia:NOTRS")_\] India emits about 7% of global greenhouse gas emissions. This equates to about 2.5 tons of [carbon dioxide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_dioxide "Carbon dioxide") per person per year, which is half the world average.[\[318\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-USAID2018-333)[\[319\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-UNEP2019-334) Increasing [access to electricity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrification "Electrification") and [clean cooking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clean_cooking "Clean cooking") with [liquefied petroleum gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liquefied_petroleum_gas "Liquefied petroleum gas") have been priorities for energy in India.[\[320\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-335) ### Socio-economic challenges [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Female_health_workers_in_India_%2834332433890%29.jpg/500px-Female_health_workers_in_India_%2834332433890%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Female_health_workers_in_India_(34332433890).jpg) Health workers about to begin another day of immunisation against infectious diseases in 2006. Eight years later, and three years after India's last case of polio, the [World Health Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Health_Organization "World Health Organization") declared India to be polio-free.[\[321\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-who-chan-14-feb-2014-336) Despite economic growth during recent decades, India continues to face socio-economic challenges. In 2006, India contained the [largest number](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poverty_in_India "Poverty in India") of people living below the World Bank's international poverty line of US$1.25 per day.[\[322\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-337) The proportion decreased from 60% in 1981 to 42% in 2005.[\[323\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-338) Under the World Bank's later revised poverty line, it was 21%-22.5 in 2011.[\[p\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-340)[\[325\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-WB2015-341)[\[326\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-povini-342) In 2019, the estimates had gone down to 10.2%.[\[326\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-povini-342) In 2014, 30.7% of India's children under the age of five were underweight.[\[327\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-343) According to a [Food and Agriculture Organization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Food_and_Agriculture_Organization "Food and Agriculture Organization") report in 2015, 15% of the population was undernourished.[\[328\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-344)[\[329\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-345) The [Midday Meal Scheme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midday_Meal_Scheme "Midday Meal Scheme") attempts to lower these rates.[\[330\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDr%C3%A8zeGoyal200846-346) A 2018 [Walk Free Foundation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walk_Free_Foundation "Walk Free Foundation") report estimated that nearly 8 million people in India were living in different forms of [modern slavery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_slavery "Modern slavery"), such as [bonded labour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bonded_labour "Bonded labour"), [child labour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Child_labour "Child labour"), human trafficking, and forced begging.[\[331\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Pandit_2018-347) According to the 2011 census, there were 10.1 million child labourers in the country, a decline of 2.6 million from 12.6 million in 2001.[\[332\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-348) Since 1991, [economic inequality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Indian_states_by_GDP "List of Indian states by GDP") between India's states has consistently grown: the per-capita [net state domestic product](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Net_domestic_product "Net domestic product") of the richest states in 2007 was 3.2 times that of the poorest.[\[333\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalGhosh2007-349) [Corruption in India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corruption_in_India "Corruption in India") is perceived to have decreased. According to the [Corruption Perceptions Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index "Corruption Perceptions Index"), India ranked 78th out of 180 countries in 2018, an improvement from 85th in 2014.[\[334\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-350)[\[335\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-351) ## Demographics, languages, and religion Main articles: [Demographics of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demographics_of_India "Demographics of India"), [Languages of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Languages_of_India "Languages of India"), and [Religion in India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religion_in_India "Religion in India") See also: [South Asian ethnic groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Asian_ethnic_groups "South Asian ethnic groups") [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Sikh_pilgrim_at_the_Golden_Temple_%28Harmandir_Sahib%29_in_Amritsar%2C_India.jpg/500px-Sikh_pilgrim_at_the_Golden_Temple_%28Harmandir_Sahib%29_in_Amritsar%2C_India.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Sikh_pilgrim_at_the_Golden_Temple_(Harmandir_Sahib)_in_Amritsar,_India.jpg) A Sikh pilgrim at the [Harmandir Sahib](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harmandir_Sahib "Harmandir Sahib"), or Golden Temple, in [Amritsar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amritsar "Amritsar"), Punjab [![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Interior_of_San_Thome_Basilica.jpg/500px-Interior_of_San_Thome_Basilica.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Interior_of_San_Thome_Basilica.jpg) The interior of [San Thome Basilica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Thome_Basilica "San Thome Basilica"), [Chennai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai "Chennai"), [Tamil Nadu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamil_Nadu "Tamil Nadu"). Christianity is believed to have been introduced to India by the late 2nd century by [Syriac-speaking Christians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christianity_in_India#Early_Christianity_in_India "Christianity in India"). With an estimated 1,428,627,663 residents in 2023, India is the world's most populous country.[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-WPP_UN-21) 1,210,193,422 residents were reported in the [2011 provisional census report](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Census_of_India "2011 Census of India").[\[336\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India160-352) Its population grew by 17.64% from 2001 to 2011,[\[337\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India165-353) compared to 21.54% growth in the previous decade (1991–2001).[\[337\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India165-353) The human sex ratio, according to the 2011 census, is 940 females per 1,000 males.[\[336\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India160-352) The median age was 28.7 in 2020.[\[280\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECentral_Intelligence_Agency-295) The first post-colonial census, conducted in 1951, counted 361 million people.[\[338\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-354) Medical advances made in the last 50 years as well as increased agricultural productivity brought about by the " [Green Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Revolution_in_India "Green Revolution in India")" have caused India's population to grow rapidly.[\[339\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTERorabacher201035%E2%80%9339-355) The life expectancy in India is at 70 years—71.5 years for women, 68.7 years for men.[\[280\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECentral_Intelligence_Agency-295) There are around 93 physicians per 100,000 people.[\[340\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-356) Migration from rural to urban areas has been an important dynamic in India's recent history. The number of people living in urban areas grew by 31.2% between 1991 and 2001.[\[341\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGarg2005-357) Yet, in 2001, over 70% still lived in rural areas.[\[342\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDysonVisaria2005115%E2%80%93129-358)[\[343\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTERatna2007271%E2%80%93272-359) The level of urbanisation increased further from 27.81% in the 2001 Census to 31.16% in the 2011 Census. The slowing down of the overall population growth rate was due to the sharp decline in the growth rate in rural areas since 1991.[\[344\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChandramouli2011-360) According to the 2011 census, there are 53 [million-plus urban agglomerations in India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_million-plus_urban_agglomerations_in_India "List of million-plus urban agglomerations in India"); among them [Mumbai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mumbai "Mumbai"), [Delhi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delhi "Delhi"), [Kolkata](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolkata "Kolkata"), [Chennai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chennai "Chennai"), [Bengaluru](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bangalore "Bangalore"), [Hyderabad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyderabad "Hyderabad") and [Ahmedabad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmedabad "Ahmedabad"), in decreasing order by population.[\[345\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-censusindia_2011-361) The literacy rate in 2011 was 74.04%: 65.46% among females and 82.14% among males.[\[346\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India163-362) The rural-urban literacy gap, which was 21.2 percentage points in 2001, dropped to 16.1 percentage points in 2011. The improvement in the rural literacy rate is twice that of urban areas.[\[344\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChandramouli2011-360) [Kerala](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kerala "Kerala") is the most literate state with 93.91% literacy; while [Bihar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bihar "Bihar") the least with 63.82%.[\[346\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEProvisional_Population_Totals_Paper_1_of_2011_India163-362) Among speakers of the [Indian languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Languages_of_India "Languages of India"), 74% speak [Indo-Aryan languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-Aryan_languages "Indo-Aryan languages"), the easternmost branch of the [Indo-European languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-European_languages "Indo-European languages"); 24% speak [Dravidian languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dravidian_languages "Dravidian languages"), indigenous to [South Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Asia "South Asia") and spoken widely before the spread of Indo-Aryan languages and 2% speak [Austroasiatic languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Austroasiatic_languages "Austroasiatic languages") or the [Sino-Tibetan languages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sino-Tibetan_languages "Sino-Tibetan languages"). India has no national language.[\[347\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDharwadker2010168%E2%80%93194,_186-363) [Hindi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindi "Hindi"), with the largest number of speakers, is the official language of the government.[\[348\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOttenheimer2008303-364)[\[349\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMallikarjun2004-365) [English](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_language "English language") is used extensively in business and administration and has the status of a "subsidiary official language";[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMinistry_of_Home_Affairs_1960-9) it is important in [education](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Education_in_India "Education in India"), especially as a medium of higher education. Each state and union territory has one or more official languages, and the constitution recognises in particular 22 "scheduled languages". The 2011 census reported the [religion in India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Religion_in_India "Religion in India") with the largest number of followers was [Hinduism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hinduism_in_India "Hinduism in India") (79.80% of the population), followed by [Islam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islam_in_India "Islam in India") (14.23%); the remaining were [Christianity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christianity_in_India "Christianity in India") (2.30%), [Sikhism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sikhism_in_India "Sikhism in India") (1.72%), [Buddhism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Buddhism_in_India "History of Buddhism in India") (0.70%), [Jainism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistics_of_Jainism "Statistics of Jainism") (0.36%) and others[\[q\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-remaining_religions-366) (0.9%).[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-Census2011religion-18) India has the [third-largest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Muslim_population#List "List of countries by Muslim population") Muslim population—the largest for a non-Muslim majority country.[\[350\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-367)[\[351\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-368) ## Culture Main article: [Culture of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Culture_of_India "Culture of India") ### Visual art Main article: [Indian art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_art "Indian art") India has a very ancient tradition of art, which has exchanged many influences with the rest of [Eurasia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurasia "Eurasia"), especially in the first millennium, when [Buddhist art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist_art "Buddhist art") spread with Indian religions to [Central](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Asia "Central Asia"), [East](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Asia "East Asia") and [Southeast Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southeast_Asia "Southeast Asia"), the last also greatly influenced by Hindu art.[\[352\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-369) Thousands of [seals from the Indus Valley Civilization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indus_Valley_civilisation#Seals "Indus Valley civilisation") of the third millennium BCE have been found, usually carved with animals, but also some with human figures. The ["Pashupati" seal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%22Pashupati%22_seal "\"Pashupati\" seal"), excavated in [Mohenjo-daro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mohenjo-daro "Mohenjo-daro"), Pakistan, in 1928–29, is the best known.[\[353\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraven199714%E2%80%9316-370)[\[354\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarle199417%E2%80%9318-371) After this there is a long period with virtually nothing surviving.[\[354\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarle199417%E2%80%9318-371)[\[355\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTERowland197046%E2%80%9347-372) Almost all surviving ancient Indian art thereafter is in various forms of religious [sculpture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_sculpture "Indian sculpture") in durable materials, or coins. There was probably originally far more in wood, which is lost. In north India [Mauryan art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mauryan_art "Mauryan art") is the first imperial movement.[\[356\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraven199735%E2%80%9346-373)[\[357\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTERowland197067%E2%80%9370-374)[\[358\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarle199422%E2%80%9324-375) In the first millennium CE, [Buddhist art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist_art "Buddhist art") spread with Indian religions to [Central](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Asia "Central Asia"), [East](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Asia "East Asia") and [Southeast Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southeast_Asia "Southeast Asia"), the last also greatly influenced by [Hindu art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindu_art "Hindu art").[\[359\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTERowland1970185%E2%80%93198,_252,_385%E2%80%93466-376) Over the following centuries a distinctly Indian style of sculpting the human figure developed, with less interest in articulating precise anatomy than [ancient Greek sculpture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_Greek_sculpture "Ancient Greek sculpture") but showing smoothly flowing forms expressing _prana_ ("breath" or life-force).[\[360\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraven199722,_88-377)[\[361\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTERowland197035,_99%E2%80%93100-378) This is often complicated by the need to give figures multiple arms or heads, or represent different genders on the left and right of figures, as with the [Ardhanarishvara](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ardhanarishvara "Ardhanarishvara") form of Shiva and [Parvati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parvati "Parvati").[\[362\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraven199718%E2%80%9319-379)[\[363\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlurton1993151-380) Most of the earliest large sculpture is Buddhist, either excavated from Buddhist [stupas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stupa "Stupa") such as [Sanchi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanchi "Sanchi"), [Sarnath](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarnath "Sarnath") and [Amaravati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amaravati_Stupa "Amaravati Stupa"),[\[364\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarle199432%E2%80%9338-381) or is rock cut [reliefs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relief "Relief") at sites such as [Ajanta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajanta_Caves "Ajanta Caves"), [Karla](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karla_Caves "Karla Caves") and [Ellora](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellora "Ellora"). Hindu and Jain sites appear rather later.[\[365\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarle199443%E2%80%9355-382)[\[366\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTERowland1970113%E2%80%93119-383) In spite of this complex mixture of religious traditions, generally, the prevailing artistic style at any time and place has been shared by the major religious groups, and sculptors probably usually served all communities.[\[367\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlurton199310%E2%80%9311-384) [Gupta art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gupta_art "Gupta art"), at its peak c. 300 CE – c. 500 CE, is often regarded as a classical period whose influence lingered for many centuries after; it saw a new dominance of Hindu sculpture, as at the [Elephanta Caves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elephanta_Caves "Elephanta Caves").[\[368\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraven1997111%E2%80%93121-385)[\[369\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichell200044%E2%80%9370-386) Across the north, this became rather stiff and formulaic after c. 800 CE, though rich with finely carved detail in the surrounds of statues.[\[370\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarle1994212%E2%80%93216-387) But in the South, under the [Pallava](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pallava_dynasty "Pallava dynasty") and [Chola dynasties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chola_dynasty "Chola dynasty"), sculpture in both stone and bronze had a [sustained period of great achievement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chola_art_and_architecture#Sculpture_and_bronzes "Chola art and architecture"); the large bronzes with Shiva as [Nataraja](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nataraja "Nataraja") have become an iconic symbol of India.[\[371\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraven1997152%E2%80%93160-388)[\[372\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlurton1993225%E2%80%93227-389) Ancient painting has only survived at a few sites, of which the crowded scenes of court life in the [Ajanta Caves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ajanta_Caves "Ajanta Caves") are by far the most important, but it was evidently highly developed, and is mentioned as a courtly accomplishment in Gupta times.[\[373\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarle1994356%E2%80%93361-390)[\[374\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTERowland1970242%E2%80%93251-391) Painted manuscripts of religious texts survive from Eastern India about the 10th century onwards, most of the earliest being Buddhist and later Jain. No doubt the style of these was used in larger paintings.[\[375\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarle1994361%E2%80%93370-392) The Persian-derived [Deccan painting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deccan_painting "Deccan painting"), starting just before the [Mughal miniature](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mughal_miniature "Mughal miniature"), between them give the first large body of secular painting, with an emphasis on portraits, and the recording of princely pleasures and wars.[\[376\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraven1997202%E2%80%93208-393)[\[377\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarle1994372%E2%80%93382,_400%E2%80%93406-394) The style spread to Hindu courts, especially [among the Rajputs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rajput_painting "Rajput painting"), and developed a variety of styles, with the smaller courts often the most innovative, with figures such as [Nihâl Chand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nih%C3%A2l_Chand "Nihâl Chand") and [Nainsukh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nainsukh "Nainsukh").[\[378\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraven1997222%E2%80%93243-395)[\[379\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarle1994384%E2%80%93397,_407%E2%80%93420-396) As a market developed among European residents, it was supplied by [Company painting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Company_painting "Company painting") by Indian artists with considerable Western influence.[\[380\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraven1997243-397)[\[381\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichell2000210-398) In the 19th century, cheap [Kalighat paintings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalighat_painting "Kalighat painting") of gods and everyday life, done on paper, were urban [folk art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Folk_art "Folk art") from [Calcutta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Calcutta "Calcutta"), which later saw the [Bengal School of Art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bengal_School_of_Art "Bengal School of Art"), reflecting the art colleges founded by the British, the first movement in [modern Indian painting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_Indian_painting "Modern Indian painting").[\[382\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichell2000210%E2%80%93211-399)[\[383\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/India#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlurton1993211-400) -
